GeolocationCoordinates.summary:
The GeolocationCoordinates interface represents the position and altitude of the device on Earth, as well as the accuracy with which these properties are calculated.
The geographic position information is provided in terms of World Geodetic System coordinates (WGS84).

GeolocationCoordinatesAltitudeAccuracy.summary: The altitudeAccuracy read-only property of the interface is a strictly positive double representing the accuracy, with a 95% confidence level, of the altitude expressed in meters. This value is null if the implementation doesn't support measuring altitude.
GeolocationCoordinatesAltitudeAccuracy.value:
A positive double representing the accuracy, with a 95% confidence level,
of the altitude expressed in meters.

GeolocationCoordinatesLatitude.summary: The latitude read-only property of the interface is a double representing the latitude of the position in decimal degrees.
GeolocationCoordinatesLatitude.value: A double representing the latitude of the position in decimal degrees.

GeolocationCoordinatesAltitude.summary: The altitude read-only property of the interface is a double representing the altitude of the position in meters above the WGS84 ellipsoid (which defines the nominal sea level surface). This value is null if the implementation cannot provide this data.

remarks.para:
-Using the Geolocation API
-The interface it belongs to.
-National Imagery and Mapping Agency Technical Report 8350.2, Third Edition (WGS84)

GeolocationCoordinatesAltitude.value:
A double representing the altitude of the position in meters above the WGS84
ellipsoid.

GeolocationCoordinatesLongitude.summary:
The longitude read-only property of the interface is a number which represents the longitude of a geographical position, specified in decimal degrees.
Together with a timestamp, given as Unix time in milliseconds, indicating a time of measurement, the GeolocationCoordinates object is part of the interface, which is the object type returned by Geolocation API functions that obtain and return a geographical position.

remarks.para:
-Using the Geolocation API
-The interface it belongs to.
-The interface, which is the top-level interface
used to return geolocation data from the Geolocation API functions
and
.

GeolocationCoordinatesLongitude.value:
The value in longitude is the geographical longitude of the location on
Earth described by the Coordinates object, in decimal degrees. The value is
defined by the World Geodetic System 1984 specification (WGS 84).
NOTEThe zero meridian (also known as the prime meridian or the
reference meridian) is not precisely the same as the Greenwich meridian that most
people think of. It is, instead, the IERS Reference Meridian, which is located 5.3 arcseconds (102
meters / 335 feet) east of the Greenwich meridian. This
is the same standard used by the Global Positioning System (GPS).

GeolocationCoordinatesHeading.summary: The heading read-only property of the interface is a double representing the direction in which the device is traveling. This value, specified in degrees, indicates how far off from heading due north the device is. 0 degrees represents true north, and the direction is determined clockwise (which means that east is 90 degrees and west is 270 degrees). If is 0 or the device is not able to provide heading information, heading is null.
GeolocationCoordinatesHeading.value: A double representing the direction in which the device is traveling.

GeolocationCoordinatesAccuracy.summary: The accuracy read-only property of the interface is a strictly positive double representing the accuracy, with a 95% confidence level, of the and properties expressed in meters.
GeolocationCoordinatesAccuracy.value:
A positive double representing the accuracy, with a 95% confidence level,
of the and
properties expressed in meters.

GeolocationCoordinatesSpeed.summary: The speed read-only property of the interface is a double representing the velocity of the device in meters per second. This value is null if the implementation is not able to measure it.
GeolocationCoordinatesSpeed.value: A double representing the velocity of the device in meters per second.

GeolocationCoordinatesToJSON.summary: The toJSON() method of the interface is a {{Glossary("Serialization","serializer")}}; it returns a JSON representation of the object.
GeolocationCoordinatesToJSON.returns: A {{jsxref("JSON")}} object that is the serialization of the object.
